The story goes in all the evolutionists books that mammals evolved from reptiles. But for this to happen, lots of physiological changes would have had to take place. I would like to focus on one: the breast. I would like to know how or why reptiles would have formed them in the first place, because at some point a breast would have to form (and be selected) from a non-breasted reptile.
 
 First of all I would like to say that any reptile -- let's say lizard -- that happened to develop a random breast would still be a lizard -- a breasted lizard, but still a lizard. In fact, no matter how many mammal body parts you stack on top of a lizard, it will always be a lizard.
 
 Second, no mutation has ever formed a new body part, such as a new breast on a lizard. Anyone who cares to dispute this is welcome to provide a link.
 
 Third, even if in fairytale land a mutation did form a breast, who's to say that actual milk would flow from it? Would there also be lobes to produce the milk? How about the milk ducts to transport the milk to the nipple? Would both these accidentally form at the same time? How?
 
 Fourth, how about a nipple? Without that there is no feeding. So which formed first, the breast, the lobes, the milk ducts, or the nipple? You can't have a functional breast without each of these...and if the breasts aren't functional then the little cold-blooded lizards who don't drink milk to begin with would never get the opportunity to do so.
 
 Fifth, aren't there some signals that need to be sent from the brain before milk starts flowing? Ah -- well yes there are:
 
 http://www.asklenore.info/breastfeeding/induced_lactation/biology.html
 
 a signal is sent to the brain from the breast to release oxytocin which initiates the milk ejection or let down reflex (MER) and causes the milk to flow. 
 
 Thus, how would a brain communicate with a feature it was not wired to communicate with? Did evolution somehow create the wiring for the breast at the same time as the milk ducts, the nipple and the breast itself?
 
 Also, how would the animal, since it is cold-blooded, keep the milk warm? You don't want your babies drinking cold milk do you?
 
 And who's to say that the male lizard wouldn't develop breasts? It's a 50/50 chance, you know. 
 
 And how would a lizard crawl around effectively with multiple breasts hanging off him/her? Wouldn't they get drug across the ground? How could he climb a tree? His/her legs wouldn't reach the trunk if the breasts were full of milk!
 
 And don't lizards have multiple offspring? Like dozens? So what if the mother lizard only has like 5 breasts ---- simple math will tell you that most will go hungry.
 
 Finally, lizards don't generally hang around and tend to their offspring after they're born -- er, hatched. So what would make a lizard go against all previous instincts just because it happened to evolve a breast?

Anogenital "sweat" glands. Histology and pathology of a gland that may mimic mammary glands.
 
 van der Putte SC.
 
 Department of Pathology, Utrecht University Hospital, University of Utrecht, The Netherlands.
 
 A new variant of cutaneous glands is described that occurs in the anogenital region, with its highest concentration in the interlabial sulcus of the vulva. The glands are characterized by a wide coiled tube from which originate acini, diverticula, and short branches; a lining of a compact simple columnar epithelium with prominent cytoplasmic snouts protruding into the lumen; and a broad mantle of loose fibromyxoid to dense collagenous connective tissue. Occasionally, true lobuli are formed resembling those of mammary glands. A close relationship to eccrine glands was evidenced by intermediate variants and the occasional observation of typical eccrine segments in otherwise characteristic anogenital glands. The glands revealed periodic changes of epithelium and stroma. Their strict localization around the derivatives of the embryonic cloacal entrance suggests a possible role in sexual functions. Their characteristic histology links and explains a series of disorders of the anogenital region in women (including functional vulvar mammary glands after pregnancy, fibrocystic disease, fibroadenoma, hidradenoma papilliferum, and some cases of adenocarcinoma, including Paget's disease) and in men [including fibroadenoma or apocrine cystadenoma, and cases of Paget's disease].

 Reptiles have laterally splayed limbs and undifferentiated teeth in a jaw which lacks latteral movement.
 Mammals support their body with their limbs vertically underneath the body and have differentiated teeth for different tasks, their jaws can move latterally, they have cheeks to hold food during this process, several bones from the reptilian jaw are now found in the mammalian ear.
 Synapsids exhibit entirely reptilian features, closely related Therapsids appear later in the fossil sequance and have differentiated teeth setting them apart from other reptiles. Cynodonts are a late form of Theraspsid where the limbs have moved into a vertically supporting position and teeth have settled into the three forms inherited by all mammals; Incisors, Canines, Molars.
 Mammaliaformes show almost all mammalian features including the migration of the reptilian jawbones into the ear.

 But since you want to learn, and since all of this seems so new to you, I'll explain what drives natural selection for you.
 
 Darwin's Explanatory Model of Natural Selection
 
 Fact 1. Every population has such high fertility that its size would increase exponentially if it were not constrained.
 
 Fact 2. The size of populations, except for temporary annual fluctuations, remains stable over time.
 
 Fact 3. The resources available to every species are limited.
 Inference 1. There is intense competition among the members of a species.
 Fact 4. No two individuals of a population are exactly the same.
 Inference 2. Individuals of a population differ from each other in the probability of survival (i.e., natural selection).
 Fact 5. Many of the differences among the individuals of a population are, at least in part, heritable.
 Inference 3. Natural selection, continued over many generations, results in evolution.
 Notice that there isn't a hint of some intelligence behind any of it. Natural selection is the probability of survival. It has also been called differential reproductive success. Perhaps that will help you to clear up the confusion that causes you to equate evolution, a process that is the result of many mechanisms, from natural selection (one of those mechanisms).

**The word 'selection' does entail at least primitive consciousness, i.e., awareness. That is simply a fact. In view of that fact, by using that term, Charles Darwin and every darwinist who has ever used 'natural selection' as the signification for a real phenomenon has implicitly endowed the term with a perceiving and comprehending awareness, value judgement/evaluation, and directed choice.
 
 To say that 'selection', like 'competition', can be unaware and involuntary is to talk pure semantic rubbish.
 
 See below, from answers.com
 
 "se·lec·tion (sĭ-lĕk'shən) 
 n.
 
 The act or an instance of selecting or the fact of having been selected.
 One that is selected.
 A carefully chosen or representative collection of people or things. See synonyms at choice.
 A literary or musical text chosen for reading or performance."
 
 Interjection. The abovwe is what 'selection' truly means. Now note the total dissimilarity between the above and the "biological" [meaning, "darwinist"] definition that follows--
 
 "Biology. A natural or artificial process that favors or induces survival and perpetuation of one kind of organism over others that die or fail to produce offspring."
 
 See? No semantic correlation that would excuse the contrived equivocation.
 Not to mention that the biological 'definition' is so nebulous as to be meaningless in any scientific context.
 
 Let's try the root word, 'to select', shall we?
 
 "se·lect (sĭ-lĕkt') 
 
 v., -lect·ed, -lect·ing, -lects.
 
 v.tr.
 To take as a choice from among several; pick out.
 
 v.intr.
 To make a choice or selection."
 
 Just try to subtract awareness, analysis, and volition from that, why don't you? Just try and turn 'to select', into a blind, come-by-chance, mindless accidental, unintentional operation, why don't you?
 

 
 Another piece of WW nonsense, which I intended to respond to but forgot.
 
 Let's repeat that first bit again for emphasis, because it is wrong: 
"The word 'selection' does entail at least primitive consciousness, i.e., awareness. That is simply a fact. In view of that fact, by using that term, Charles Darwin and every darwinist who has ever used 'natural selection' as the signification for a real phenomenon has implicitly endowed the term with a perceiving and comprehending awareness, value judgement/evaluation, and directed choice."

 
 Let's see what Darwin actually said on this matter, because he was, in fact, quite explicit that he intended otherwise: 
(from the 5th edition of the Origin of Species) Others have objected that the term selection implies conscious choice in the animals which become modified; and it has even been urged that, as plants have no volition, natural selection is not applicable to them! In the literal sense of the word, no doubt, natural selection is a false term; but who ever objected to chemists speaking of the elective affinities of the various elements?-and yet an acid cannot strictly be said to elect the base with which it in preference combines. It has been said that I speak of natural selection as an active power or Deity; but who objects to an author speaking of the attraction of gravity as ruling the movements of the planets? Every one knows what is meant and is implied by such metaphorical expressions; and they are almost necessary for brevity. So again it is difficult to avoid personifying the word Nature; but I mean by Nature, only the aggregate action and product of many natural laws, and by laws the sequence of events as ascertained by us. With a little familiarity such superficial objections will be forgotten.

 
 Darwin explains elsewhere that he chose "natural selection" as a comparison to artificial selection, by breeding plus culling. He saw that 'nature" (events in the normal courses of the lives of the members of a species) were directly but unconciously culling the species and conferring on them very different degrees of reproductive success.
 
 (However, Darwin was in fact wrong on the last point, in failing to anticipate WW.)

Indeed the concept of selection and selectivity are deeply embedded in science and technology. We speak of selective filters, selective reactions, selective mechanical processes, selective this and selective that. And its all process related. Suppose we have things with a composition vector Xi and those things are subjected to a process such that Xi give rise to Xj. If Xit is the total count of Xi and Xjt is the total count for Xj then selection is present if the input vector Xi/Xit is not equal to the output vector Xj/Xjt. In other words selectivity only requires that the composition vector changes during the process.
 
 This is of course what Darwin meant by the term and it does not in any way require that the process involved be intelligent, intentional, externally directed, or anything but existant.
 
 One can joust in the verbal mode forever on this sort of thing, but a simple and clear mathematical definition leaves no room to debate what we mean by selection. Its clumsy here without notational conveniences and one is forced to use words instead, but surely even WW can grasp the actual meaning as intended by biologists and chemists etc. Common usage and technical usage often are a loggerheads, but technical usage is usually tightly defined by those who use the term. Selection is such a term. WW is simply wrong here.
 
 And one must needs consider Darwins admonitions. The term is in fact "natural selection" which implies selection caused by natural processes or variables and indeed the contrarst to "artificial selection" done by humans which IS volitional, intentional, and directed to a goal is striking. "Natural selection" has none of those properties you realize. The processes underlying natural selection are not set in place by minds (divine or human) but rather by the operation of nature via (ultimately) physics and chemistry.
 
 Now just for the fun of it lets apply the dictionary to the term "natural selection" and what turns up?
